title: china pangolins traditional medicine coronavirus animal trade
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Some scientists believe pangolins incubate the Covid-19 virusThe Independent employs over 100 journalists around the world to bring you news you can trust. Please consider a contribution or subscription.China has removed pangolin parts from its list of traditional medicines, state-backed media reported, in a move campaigners say is a vital step in helping to protect the endangered animal.Pangolins – the world’s most trafficked mammal  – are highly sought after in China and Vietnam for their meat which is considered a delicacy, while their scales are used in traditional medicine and folk remedies.Similar in size to domestic cats and the only mammal covered in scales, all eight pangolin species are protected under international laws but there remains a growing illegal trade of the animals. Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThis week health authorities omitted pangolin scales from China’s latest Pharmacopoeia, an approved list of traditional drugs and remedies due to “wild resources exhaustion”, according to a report in the Health Times.WildAid CEO Peter Knights said the move was “the greatest single action that could have been taken to save pangolins from extinction.”“The increased protection coupled with the swift and comprehensive closure of live wildlife markets and removal of many wild species from the list of what can be consumed as food in China were already very positive steps to saving the pangolin worldwide and reducing the possibility of them ever being a vector for disease.“And now this announcement, effectively the closure of legal sales of pangolin scales, shutting the last major loophole in pangolin protection efforts,” he added.People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) welcomed China’s decision, but urged action to stop the sale of pangolins on the black market. “PETA gives a nod to China for taking an important step to combat the demand for pangolin scales,” director Elisa Allen told The Independent.“However, as long as it remains desirable and profitable for endangered animals’ body parts to be sold for medicine, wildlife will continue to be killed on the black market.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“We urge the Chinese government to clamp down on the use of animal-derived substances for medicine – whether it’s pangolin scales, donkey skin for ejiao, or horse urine for Premarin, which is also an issue in the West.”The move comes after China’s forestry authority last week upgraded the status of pangolins to “first-level protected wild animal,” the highest possible protection status alongside pandas and tigers.Trade in pangolins is banned in China but it is estimated that between 116,990 and 233,980 were killed between 2011 and 2013, according to the World Wildlife Fund, but experts fears those numbers are just the tip of the iceberg.Last year alone, authorities seized more than 130 tons of pangolin related products, a figure estimated to represent up to 400,000 animals, according to conservation group WildAid.Gilbert Sape, Head of Traditional Medicine at World Animal Protection called for a permanent ban on wildlife trade, saying it wwas ”the only long-term solution to keeping wild animals wild, eliminating animal suffering, and all importantly, preventing major health epidemics.”Pangolins eat ants, termites and larvae. Some scientists believe they may incubate the Covid-19 virus that is thought to have emerged in Wuhan last year and has since swept the globe.Scientists find virus similar to Covid-19 in pangolinsFollowing the outbreak of coronavirus at the end of last year, China banned the consumption of all wild animals in a bid to prevent further outbreaks but many wet markets have since reopened.Earlier this year, The Independent renewed its call for the banning of trade in wild animals to help protect endangered species and avoid future pandemics.“These actions of China will have a real impact, these are steps that were critical, that needed to be taken if real conservation was going to happen for these animals,” said David Olson, director of Conservation at WWF Hong Kong.“Most of the demand for pangolin is coming from traditional Chinese medicine and consumption. title: australia world largest green turtle colony environment wildlife
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Scientists use drones as new method for counting turtles, producing more accurate resultsScientists have discovered that the world’s largest population of green turtles is nearly twice as big as previously thought, after drones allowed them to observe the animals better.About 64,000 nesting green turtles were filmed waiting to lay their eggs on Raine Island, a vegetated coral cay located on the outer edges of the Great Barrier Reef.Australian researchers from the Great Barrier Reef Foundation’s Raine Island Recovery Project said using a drone helped them accurately count thousands of turtles, a task too difficult to do “from a small boat in rough weather”.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesTheir findings, which were published in scientific journal PLOS ONE, compared three methods for counting the turtles as they made their way to the nesting grounds on Raine Island.Richard Fitzpatrick, a research partner from the Biopixel Oceans Foundation, said previous vessel-based counts were inaccurate.‘Two bin lorries a day’ of microfibres entering European waterwaysDavid Attenborough says saving the planet ‘is within reach’ Whoopi Goldberg voices animated short from Extinction RebellionFive surprising things you never knew contained plasticPPE washes up off French coast“When we compared drone counts to observer counts, we found that we had under-estimated the numbers in the past by a factor of 1.73.“By using drones, we have adjusted historical data. What previously took a number of researchers a long time can now be accomplished by one drone operator in minutes.”The paper’s lead author Dr Andrew Dunstan, of the Queensland Department of Environment and Science, said: “Previous population survey methods involved painting a white stripe down the green turtle’s carapace when they were nesting on the beach, then getting on a small boat and counting painted and non-painted turtles.“Our eyes are attracted much more to a turtle with a bright white stripe than an unpainted turtle, but the pain washed off after a few days and the counting accuracy suffered.“Trying to accurately count thousands of painted and unpainted turtles from a small boat in rough weather was difficult. Using a drone is easier, safer, much more accurate and the data is permanently stored,” he added.Managing director of the Great Barrier Reef Foundation, Anna Marsden, congratulated the researchers and described the images produced by the drone as “extraordinary”.“Raine Island is the world’s largest green turtle nesting site and that’s why we’re working with our Raine Island Recovery Project partners to protect and restore the island’s critical habitat,” she said.“We’re taking action to improve and rebuild the island’s nesting beaches and building fences to prevent turtle deaths, all working to strengthen the island’s resilience and ensure the survival of our northern green turtles and many other species.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus poverty pandemic study world bank covid 19
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Increase&nbspwould mark the first absolute rise in&nbspglobal poverty count since 1999The Independent employs over 100 journalists around the world to bring you news you can trust. Please consider a contribution or subscription.The number of people in extreme poverty around the world could rise beyond 1 billion as a result of the Covid-19 crisis, new analysis has suggested.Figures from the World Bank suggest that 736 million people currently live in destitution, surviving on less than $1.90 a day (£1.53).But in a study published on Friday, researchers at King’s College London and Australian National University have warned that the pandemic could trigger “substantial” poverty increases and reverse decades’ worth of progress.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesDifferent scenarios of consumption and income contraction during lockdown were modelled to establish the economic shock of Covid-19 at three poverty levels – $1.90, $3.20 (£2.58) and $5.50 (£4.43) per day.The study found that an additional 395 million people across the world could be forced below the $1.90 line by the pandemic.How to help the elderly and vulnerable during the coronavirusHow to feel less anxious about the coronavirusHow to be productive when working from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsThis figure rises to 527 million people when considering the highest poverty classification of $5.50 a day. In this scenario, more than one-sixth of the world’s population would be living in some form of extreme poverty.These increases would mark the first absolute rise in the global poverty count since 1999, the study said, adding that the cost of the pandemic in lost income is estimated to reach $500m (£394m) per day for the world’s poorest people.“Millions of people live in a precarious position one shock away from poverty,” Andy Sumner, co-author of the study and an international development professor at King’s College London, told the The Independent. “The current crisis could be that shock that pushes them over the edge.”Dr Sumner warned that the distribution and location of global poverty could also shift away from sub-Saharan Africa towards developing and middle-income countries in south and east Asia, such as Indonesia, the Philippines and Bangladesh.“The narrative for a few years has been poverty is becoming more and more about sub-saharan Africa,” he said. “But because there is a lot of people just above the poverty line in different parts of Asia, which has a lot of very populous countries, we could easily see a relocation of the overall picture of global poverty.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“We tend to see the world’s poor as focused in incredibly poor countries, but most live in countries that have been doing okay, at least until Covid-19. Now there’s an awful lot of people who have moved just above the poverty who could quite easily fall back.”Poorer pupils face 'epidemic of educational poverty' amid school delayCoronavirus could lead to ‘historic reduction’ in global povertyMinisters urged to protect carers from ‘growing poverty crisis’ The study, which was published by the United Nations University World Institute for Development Economics Research (UNU-WIDER), called for urgent action from global leadership to address the impact of Covid-19 on world poverty.Writing for The Independent, Dr Sumner proposed three forms of action to counter the effects of the pandemic. These are:Creating a&nbsprapid-response global commission on poverty and Covid-19 chaired by a G7 leader, a G20 leader and a G77 leader to discuss the poverty impacts and what financing is neededReleasing funds quickly by expanding the existing IMF debt servicing standstill to all developing countries and freezing World Bank debt repayments at least until the end of 2020Swiftly allocating the newly available funds into countries’ own cash transfer and other social safety programmes“The actual poverty impacts will be determined by what governments do to mitigate the damaging consequences of the pandemic,” he added. “The world’s poorest can’t wait until the G7 meet in September or the G20 meet in November.”Pointing to the example of the Asian financial crash of the late 1990s, which saw a number of government regimes reshaped and reformed in the aftermath, Dr Sumner said the sharp increases in poverty from Covid-19 could similarly “lead to major social upheaval of some kind” in the global south.The researchers also raised concern over the distribution of a Covid-19 vaccine among the developing world, saying “there is no guarantee everyone would get it for free” while highlighting how it could reshape social lines.“Will we end up living in a new Covid-19 apartheid with the vaccinated and non-vaccinated residing in separate areas and working in different labour markets? While this might sound far off, already now there are some countries issuing ‘immunity passports’,” the paper says.Professor Kunal Sen, director of UNU-WIDER, described the new poverty estimates as “sobering”. “We cannot stand by and see the hard work and effort of so many be eradicated,” he said.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: campsites holiday parks open uk july 4
story: Campsites and holiday parks all over the UK will be opening July , but there are a few key changes being made to sites that you really need to look into before you book. Heres what we know.Holidays away from the UK are highly unlikely over the next few months as Britain continues to fight the coronavirus pandemic.Campsites are opening July , and its highly likely that holiday parks like Butlins, Haven and Centre Parks will be following suit.However social distancing rules are being implemented across the board in answer to concerns around campsites reliance on communal areas and bathrooms.Scotland and Wales have dferent rules to England, so please check your specic site with the links below as the situation could change at any minute.This is the situation with most UK holiday resorts for the time being:Away resorts: Opening July .Butlins: All parks are closed until July . If youve booked for before then you can get your money back here.The Caravan and Motorhome Club: All sites are to reopen in England from July  as part of phase three, Scotland is expected to start reopening July  and Welsh sites are subject to permission, so please check here.The Camping and Caravanning Club: The company is opening the majority of its English sites on July .The organisation will not be operating any of their glamping-style Ready Camp Safari Tents, Pods or Self-Catering units this season.Centre Parcs: Center Parcs villages are remaining closed until July  while Longford Forest is closed until July .Flower of May: All parks are closed until early July when some of their larger parks will reopen, but details are still to be announced.Haven: All sites are closed until July .Hoeseasons: Accepting bookings from July  in England, July  in Wales and July  in Scotland. Customers who booked before July  are being contacted.Holidaylettings: The company is allowing free cancellations for bookings starting on or before July . They have not said when they are reopening.John Fowler Holidays: Has shut all parks until July , and are offering refunds or rescheduled holidays.Lyons Holiday Parks: Has cancelled all holidays up to June  and are currently offering  holidays at  prices.Parkdean Resorts: All of Parkdeans  parks are remaining closed until July , but may be able to open after this.Park Holidays:  new bookings will only be taken with an arrival date on or after th July.Pontins holiday parks: will reopen from July  after shutting because of coronavirus.Woolacombe Bay Holidays Parks: Closed until July , subject to change.Despite easing of lockdown measures, the government insists you must continue to always stay two metres away from people not in your household.There will be a number of changes at the campsites in order to comply with social distancing and good hygiene practices to prevent the spread of coronavirus.That means that many campsites could be forced to open without access to the toilet and shower blocks.Other changes to the sites include:Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccann latest news update
story: Former cop Dave Edgar also warned people not to jump to conclusions about the guilt of the new suspect” currently in custody.It comes as the German prosecutor in the Madeleine McCann case told The Sun that Portuguese police are still convinced Maddie McCann’s parents are involved in her death.Christian Wolters, Braunschweig state prosecutor, is convinced Christian B is the main suspect and Kate and Gerry McCann dont have anything to do with it.Christian B has been named as the prime suspect in the investigation after the three-year-old went missing in Portugal in .The convicted paedo, , is currently serving time for drugs and rape in Kiel prison in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany.The states justice minister, Claus Christian Claussen, said: He is in a single cell for Christian Bs safety and security against possible attacks from other inmates.Madeleine is believed to have been murdered soon after she was kidnapped, the German prosecutor leading the investigation has said.This comes after a British ex-girlfriend of Christian B claimed the night before the toddler vanished he told her: “I have a horrible job to do in Praia da Luz tomorrow.”She also said how she asked himhe snatched Madeleine McCann and he warned: “Just don’t go there.”Follow our live blog below for all the latest news and updates.We blogged earlier that Madeleines grandmother Eileen McCann died last month of a coronavirus-related illness.Mrs McCann never got to hear that German police believe Madeleine is dead, or that a prime suspect in her disappearance has been identied.But she always believed the little girl would be found.And now a top detective once hired by the family to search for Madeleine says he also believe she could still be alive.And former cop Dave Edgar also warned people not to #jump to conclusions about the guilt of the new suspect” currently in custody.He said: “Without a body, there is still a great deal of hope for the McCanns their daughter is still alive.# Image: PAThe Madeleine McCann case has never been far from the headlines.In May , Gerry and Kate McCann were staying in a holiday apartment in Praia da Luz, Portugal with their three children.The couple went for dinner with a group of friends in a nearby restaurant, leaving their three children asleep.They checked on them during the evening # but when Kate looked in at around pm, she discovered Madeleine was gone.Despite a huge international search, the little girl was never found.A Met Police investigation began in , and has so far cost more than £million.But despite the identication of new suspects and persons of interest over the years, the mystery has never been solved.Christian B was identied as the prime suspect earlier this month.Image: PAThe main suspect in Madeleine McCanns disappearance allegedly broke into his exs flat and hid under the bed in case she brought another man home.The woman was left traumatised by the incident, which allegedly took place three years before Madeleine was snatched from her holiday home in Praia da Luz on Portugal’s Algarve.She told the Mirror: #I peeked under and got the shock of my le. He was hiding under there, lying on his back, staring at me.“He got out from under the bed, acted like everything was normal, said goodbye to me, walked out and closed the door behind him.“I was there all alone, just shaking and shaking.”Some big news from this morning is that the prime suspect in Madeleine McCanns disappearance could have had a secret third car.It comes after we reported earlier this week that police are continuing to probe newly-unearthed satellite pictures of Christian Bs campervan.The pictures were taken days after Madeleine vanished.A Spanish investigator has spent days scouring old satellite imagery for the van.The image could prove crucial because it suggests the distinctive van was taken back to open land Christian B was familiar with after living close-by for six years. More on our most recent blog post now.Christian Bs ex girlfriend, a -year-old barmaid from Berkshire, said he was driving a third car that police dont yet know about in mid-.The woman, who asks not to be named, moved to the Algarve town of Lagos in late  and worked at the Taberna de Lagos restaurant alongside Christian B, who was working as a waiter.Its hoped the revelation could help cops solve the case.The suspects ex has told the Mirror: #Towards the end of our relationship he had another car as well as the Jaguar.“I haven’t seen that mentioned anywhere. It was a Volkswagen. I don’t remember the model. It was a dirty, yellowy, mustardy kind of colour.“It was an old one and was long. I heard he still had it around the time Madeleine disappeared, along with the Jaguar.#Image: ReutersTheres a big development to report on the case this morning.The ex-girlfriend of the prime suspect, Christian B, says he had a secret third car in Portugal # and she believes it could hold vital evidence.Detectives are already looking into two vehicles owned by the suspect.But its now believed he also owned a Volkswagen estate at the time of Madeleines disappearance too. Detectives involved in the investigation of the case previously released photos of two vehicles linked with the suspect # a white camper van and black Jaguar. Madeleine McCanns grandmother Eileen, who never gave up hope that her granddaughter would be found, has died.Mrs McCann, , passed away from a coronavirus-related illness last month # weeks before German police revealed they believe little Madeleine is dead and they are now investigating a new prime suspect.Shortly after her granddaughter was snatched in , Mrs McCann # mum of Madeleines dad Gerry # said: #When I lost my husband two years ago, I thought that my world had collapsed.#But losing Madeleine is ten times worse.#Heres the full story.Christian B told an ex-lover he had “a horrible job” to do the night before Madeleine disappeared.The woman is one of two British former girlfriends of the child sex offender who were dating him while he was in Praia da Luz, Portugal, and have now given evidence to police.She has told of a chilling conversation she had with him over dinner on May ,  the night before Madeleine, three, was abducted.The then -year-old drter told her: #I have a job to do in Praia da Luz tomorrow. Its a horrible job but its something I have to do and it will change my le. You wont be seeing me for a while.#Christian B disappeared at the same time as Madeleine resurfacing three years later working in a bar in Lagos, around km from Praia da Luz.Christian B has refused to talk about Madeleines disappearance, his lawyer revealed earlier this week.He has remained tight-lipped in the high security German prison where he is doing seven years for rape and another jail term for drugs offences.But his lawyer Friedrich Fülscher suggested his client would deny the chargesGerman cops uncover enough evidence to prosecute him for Maddie’s murder.Mr Fülscher spoke after visiting Christian B at the prison in Kiel, northern Germany, where he is in isolation.When asked how his client was doing he replied: “How can a person, who is isolated in a prison and whom half the worlds population accuses of the worst crimes, be ”He said he would act “under civil or criminal law# against any  statements made against his client.And he added: #Christian B. is currently not providing any information on the matter and we ask for your understanding that we, as defence lawyers, are also not providing any information.#Madeleines grandmother Eileen “who never gave up hope” that she would be found has died from a Covid--related illness.Eileen McCann, , died last month weeks before German prosecutors revealed they believed the child was murdered while naming new suspect Christian B.Following Madeleines disappearance in , Gerry’s mother Eileen, from Glasgow, said: “As long as they don’t find her body, I’ll never give up hope. “When we do finally get her home she’ll have so much love and hugs from us all.”Thats all from us today, but heres a wrap up of the days main stories.GERMAN prosecutors investigating the prime suspect in the Madeleine McCann case has called on Sun readers to turn detective and solve the mystery.Hans Wolters is convinced rapist Christian B, , is responsible for her murder but is desperate for help from Brits who may hold the key to cracking the crime.Mr Wolters said they had “strong evidence” and added they were sure Madeleine “has been murdered” but still needed more information to make the case against him stick.He said: “We need the help of the readers of The Sun. Maybe there are some British tourists who spent their time between  and  in Portugal, in Praia da Luz, and took some video or pictures.“I hope there are some readers of The Sun who can help us to find the murderer of Madeleine McCann.“Many British tourists spend their holidays there and maybe they have pictures of the suspect or something interesting for our investigation.”The boss and former pal of Madeleine McCann suspect Christian B sensationally claimed #we all know# what happened to the missing tot.Tiziano Ilg hired the fellow German at his restaurant when the paedophile suddenly turned up in the remote village of Foral in the weeks following Maddies disappearance.Ilg, now in his late s and still living in the region, has kept a low profile since German police identied his old worker as a prime suspect in Maddies case.And its understood he has not spoken to police about his fellow countryman.But in  the former restaurateur claimed it was #time to stop looking# for three-year-old Madeleine, who disappeared some miles away from his Foral restaurant.Responding to an online news article about her disappearance, Ilg cryptically said: #Its time to stop looking and stop imagining.#We all know.#Full story below." title"#Ex-boss of Madeleine McCann suspect sensationally claimed #we all know# what happened to the missing toddler# # The Sun" src"https:www.thesun news  madeleine-mccan-suspect-boss-knew-claim embed # secretEriEkMmEPm" data-secret"EriEkMmEPm" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Top detective Dave Edgar has said there is a #huge way to go from Christian B being named as a suspect to him being prosecuted.He told The Sun: #Secondly, this case is still without a body. And without a body, there is no evidence Madeleine was murdered,# he said.“Without a body, there is still a great deal of hope for the McCanns their daughter is still alive.#His claims contradict those of German prosecutors who say there is enough proof to convince them Madeleine was killed after being abducted.However, the retired detective said there is still no “hard evidence” the youngster has actually been killed.The step-dad of a girl who vanished near where Madeleine McCann was taken has urged police to quiz Christian B about her disappearance.Joana Cipriano was eight when she went missing from Figueira, just five miles from Praia da Luz, in .Step-dad Leandro Silva has called on German and Portuguese police to investigate any links between Madeleine’s suspect and Joana.The young girl’s mum, Leonor Cipriano, and uncle, Joao Cipriano, were convicted of murdering the eight-year-old, although her body has never been found.The pair served nearly two decades in jail, but Mr Silva still claims that they are innocent.Madeleine McCann vanished from her family’s holiday apartment in Portugal in  where she was sleeping alongside her twin siblings Sean and Amelie.Now aged , the twins have grown up without knowing their older sister who is still missing.Sean and Amelie live with parents Kate and Gerry at their home in the town of Loughborough in Leicestershire.They attend a Catholic secondary school the area which retains a place for their sister Madeleine, who would be aged  now,she is ever found.The twins are both aspiring athletes and have competed in triathlons and country crossing racing.Sean and Amelie were aged only two at the time of their sister’s disappearance on May , .Former GP Kate, now a medical worker, said her twins have “grown up essentially without Madeleine but knowing their sister is missing and they want her back.”Heres a summary of all the latest updates today.Portuguese prosecutors have confirmed Madeleine McCann suspect Christian B served two jail sentences in the country.It was reported last week that the -year-old had served time in Portugal, but authorities have now revealed his criminal record.Last night prosecutors took the unusual step of confirming Christian B had been convicted of “disobedience” and “theft”.A spokesman for the Faro District of the Portuguese Public Prosecution Service said: “The Maddie suspect was convicted of disobedience in one case and of theft in another.“Five requests for international judicial cooperation were also found in which the name of the suspect is mentioned.“One of the requests is related to a case actioned against unknown people and closed in February , and four related to the investigation into Madeleine McCann’s disappearance.”Local media had reported that the -year-old spent two months in Evora Prison, in central Portugal, and nine months in jail in the Algarve for petrol theft in .Prime suspect Christian B broke into his British ex’s flat sparking chilling echoes of the Madeleine McCann case, according to reports.The convicted sex fiend was so insanely jealous he hid under the woman’s bed in case she brought another man home.His ex, from Berkshire, moved to the Algarve town of Lagos in late  and worked at the Taberna de Lagos restaurant alongside waiter Christian B, who was two years younger.The -year-old barmaid # who has asked not to be identied # came home alone and was horried when he appeared under her bed before coolly walking away.She was left traumatised by the incident, three years before three-year-old Maddie was snatched from her holiday home in Praia da Luz on Portugal’s Algarve.Recalling the incident, she told the Daily Mirror: #I peeked under and got the shock of my le. He was hiding under there, lying on his back, staring at me.“He got out from under the bed, acted like everything was normal, said goodbye to me, walked out and closed the door behind him.“I was there all alone, just shaking and shaking.”A barmaid has recalled the moment Christian B shouted at her #the child is dead# when colleagues discussed Madeleine McCanns disappearance.The suspect is said to have got #very aggressive, nervous and agitated# as workers at a kiosk he ran in his hometown of Braunschweig brought up the toddler.Chief suspect Christian B is said to have boasted about torture and destroying evidence in an online conversation with another paedophile.He made chilling threats about wanting to “catch something little and use it for days”.German cops investigating the disappearance of Inga Gehricke, five, – which Christian B has also been linked to – discovered the conversation.During the chat, when Christian B was asked about being caught, he reportedly said: “Meh,the evidence is destroyed . . .”He then added: “Then I’ll record maaaany videos clips. I’ll document in detail how she’s being tortured.”Madeleine McCann suspect Christian B had a #hair trigger temper# and threatened a pal with a kne, a German documentary revealed last night.Former pal Norbert M spoke of the -year-olds temper on the RTL two-hour special.He said: #In , I took over a kiosk that had previously been run by him.“He wanted to take a freezer and the air conditioning with him, even though they didnt belong to him. He was very aggressive.#A short time later he showed up here with some acquaintances. One of them threatened me with a kne.“This was a shock. As a neighbour, I used to shopping with him. My experience was that he was quite friendly.#But that could change. He blew hit and cold.#Ex private detective Dave Edgar has said it would be dficult to pin anything on Christian B as so much time has passed since the disappearance.“If it wasn’t detected in the first year then it’s going to be very dficult to detect after that, unless you’ve got some sort of hard evidence – i.e. – forensic evidence or identications that are going to stand up,# he warned.“Andyou haven’t got that sort of evidence to build a case from  years down the line, it’s going to be very dficult to do. That’s an understatement – it’s going to be damned hard.#Top detective Dave Edgar said the identication of the new prime suspect Christian B brought back chilling memories of his probe into a British sex fiend.Raymond Hewlett was once believed to hold the key to the missing childs disappearance.During his hunt for the little girl, Edgar probed now-dead paedophile Raymond Hewlett’s apparent links to Madeleine’s disappearance.Like the new suspect, Hewlett lived in a battered camper-van in the Praia da Luz area and had committed a string of sexual offences against young girls.Hewlett, , was living just an hour’s drive from where Madeleine disappeared in the Algarve in May .But he died in  of throat cancer after spending years refusing to talk about the theory.The detective said: “Hewlett was definitely a person of interest to us. He was someone capable of abducting a child as he had the background and profile to interfere with children.“I tried my best to speak to him, but he wouldn’t speak. But there was just no evidence to link him to the case beyond his background – absolutely no evidence.“Yes, he was someone we were interested in, but in terms of real evidence, there wasn’t any, unless the Portuguese are sitting on some that I don’t know about.”Former cop Dave Edgar, speaking to The Sun, added that now is #not a time for knee-jerk reactions#.He said: #It’s time to just put the brakes on the speculation, and step back. It’s not a time for knee-jerk reactions.#The expert added he does not believe the lack of a body fits the profile of a kidnapping by a stranger.“In my experience, when strangers kill children, orstrangers kill anyone for that matter, they do one thing very quickly and they do it almost automatically – they dump the body of their victim so they’re not caught with it,# he revealed.“That’s just the way it works.#Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family woes the queen let go of reigns
story: Unencumbered by a relentless schedule of pressing the flesh around the country, she’s having the first extended break of her admirably dutul le.A rare sighting of her on horseback shows her deep in thought, perhaps reflecting, as we all do in moments of quiet contemplation, on the well- being of her loved ones. In her case, it’s not pretty.Where to start  How about son number two who, thanks to his friendship with billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein is now embroiled in an ugly, cross-Atlantic ding dong with an American legal system that kowtows to no one.Clearly, Andrew hoped his royal status might ensure discretion. But the US Department of Justice has other ideas and has now publicly accused him of lying when he says he has offered to co-operate with their inquiries into Epstein’s questionable activities.It’s uncertain whether The Queen and Prince Philip have Netflix in their lockdown lair at Windsor Castle, butthey have watched the documentary Jeffrey Epstein: Filthy Rich — in which their reportedly favourite son is mentioned many times — they will have spat out their popcorn.Aside from the well- documented claim by Virginia Roberts that she was trafficked to London at the age of  to have sex with Prince Andrew , one of the most damning accusations is the alleged sighting of him at Epstein’s private island where airport staff now say that the billionaire, who allegedly killed himself last year, frequently arrived with “underage girls”.Ordinary people staying schtum at the time for fear of losing their jobs is one thing but the silence of the many powerful men who enjoyed Epstein’s hospitality is quite another.Prince Andrew is undoubtedly one of them and, at the very least, he owes it to Epstein’s survivors to sit down with the US Department of Justice and reveal what he does, or doesn’t, know.And asthat’s not enough to give his mother sleepless nights, he and his ex-we Sarah Ferguson are also being sued for a £.million unpaid debt on a Swiss ski chalet.Meanwhile, son number oneis happy enough in his second marriage, but reportedly harbouring a deep sadness that one of his sons has chosen to leg it to the US, along with the baby grandson he can no longer hug.On top of that, he faces forking out millions to help Harry and Meghan pay for personal protection because not only have they chosen to settle down in paparazzi central, but in a country where the gun culture means any nutter can wander into a store and arm up as easily as buying a microwave.Son number threehas just announced that his children won’t use royal titles and will work for a living.But one wonders whether, given the pressure to streamline the monarchy, they jumped before they were pushed.Daughter Anne is a reliable stalwart, but grandson Peter recently announced his marriage to we Autumn is over, and as for grandsons William and Harry, it’s fair to say that the reported fall-out of those two young brothers who walked so stoically behind their mother’s coffin must be causing The Queen great sadness.So, with all that going on with her nearest and dearest, how will she feel when lockdown finally lts and she’s expected to put on a brave face to the world again Will she think, “I’ve had enough” and, as was rumoured prior to the pandemic, abdicate on her th birthday next year Doubtful, given that she pledged she would be of service “my whole le” and that, traditionally, British monarchs occupy the throne until death.But, given her family ructions, who could blame hershe did decide to call it a day If he had bodyguards with him on his ious visits to Epstein, then perhaps they could enlighten the US authorities on Andrew’s movements at the time Andhe didn’t, then why the hell does he need them now Asthe new, -day quarantine rule wasn’t daft enough, it’s emerged that police have been told to take “no immediate action”a passenger gives a  address on arrival in the UK.Right. So the only travellers affected by this ludicrous policy will be the law-abiding and public figures who risk being spotted on holiday then named and shamedthey don’t self-isolate upon .Everyone  can just give their details as Mickey Mouse of Taking The Mickey Street, and go about their le with impunity.Meanwhile, the airline industry is teetering on the verge of bankruptcy because it sends out the message that Britain is closed.Well. Done. Everyone.Prince Albert of Monaco has a problem – his subjects are getting too old.According to the BBC documentary Inside Monaco, it’s the most elderly country on Earth.So the principality has launched an “influencer” award aimed at attracting a younger “YouTube” generation who,the footage of their garish supercars is anything to go by, have money but zero taste.The awards are the brainchild of the prince’s friend . . .  . . .  Princess Camilla of Bourbon Two Sicilies, Duchess of Castro If Little Britain ever doesto our screens, she’s a shoo-in.Dancing On Ice is reportedly considering filming the show with two-metre social-distancing measures in place.If the rumours of their big fallout are true, last series contestant Caprice and her dance partner Hamish Gaman would have had no trouble with implementing it.Pixar’s animated movie Coco has been voted the most tear-jerking film of all time, with Marley  Me in second place and Schindler’s List in third.It was the result of a Twitter survey by US film critic Kevin Lee, who asked followers to tell him “the hardest you’ve ever cried in a movie TV show”.I haven’t seen Coco, but my weepiest, cinematic experience didn’t make the top ten.It’s Mask – starring Cher and Eric Stolz – a film that rendered me so inconsolable that the man in front of me askedI could “shut the hell up”.And Goodbye Mr Chips wasn’t far behind either – but at least I was home on the sofa for that one.Other than Leonardo DiCaprio browsing for a new girlfriend, who actually shops at underwear store Victoria’s Secret any more Not many Brits, it seems – its  UK stores have just gone in to administration.Back in the day, VS underwear was tasteful and good quality, but somewhere along the way it lost sight of its core customer.The owners clearly forgot that, while men lusted after the scantily-clad “Angels” such as Alessandra Ambrosio at its catwalk shows , it’s primarily women who buy lingerie.And the majority want “tastefully boudoir” not “garishly bordello”.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says government bolder two metre rule schools
story: He has been held back by the intransigence of the unions, parents’ Covid fears and Public Health England’s advice which, as so often, now looks dubious.Labour, true to form, backed the unions over our children, especially the most disadvantaged who are suffering worst.The Left threw up endless roadblocks, claiming it wasn’t safe to .Then, when the Government had little choice but to U-turn on getting all primary kids back before the summer, Labour squealed that a generation was being betrayed. What a hypocritical shambles.But the bigger problem is PHE’s advice to cap class sizes at , making normal school le all but impossible in terms of staffing and space.Its two-metre social-distancing rule is virtually impossible to maintain too, especially in playgrounds.And the reality is that now looks hugely over­cautious and is sabotaging both schools and businesses desperate to reopen.The WHO only recommended one metre. Our scientists doubled it for good measure.Fair enough, perhaps, when infections were soaring.Not now that less than one in , people in England — and falling fast — has Covid.Yes, the virus can kill in extreme circumstances.But our chances of getting it are tiny at two metres and STILL tiny at one.Especially with routine mask use.International studies show reopening schools has barely any effect on increasing infections, among kids or adults.The Government is on the ropes, only prepared to make timid and incremental changes which lead to chaotic and baffling new rules like the new “bubbles” for people living alone.It simply has to be bolder, starting by relaxing the two-metre rule.Now, before it does any more damage.IT’S quite the confession.The same Sage scientists who unanimously advised the Government against an earlier lockdown now say it came too late and may have killed thousands.What, then, should Boris have decided after receiving that advice on March  Perhaps he should have told Britain’s finest epidemiologists: “You clueless clowns don’t know what you’re talking about”, as his prominent critics apparently believe.Instead he deferred to their expertise.Imagine the howling rage of Remainer MPs, journalists and punditsthis Vote Leave Government had not done so.These same champions of hindsight — who had a hissy-fit both over Dominic Cummings attending Sage meetings and over Boris attending too few — now suggest No dithered. But they didn’t.The advice was clear and unanimous. They followed it.The mental gymnastics necessary to blame the Tories for doing both too little and too much, too fast and too slow, would win gold at every Olympics.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sir geoff palmer keep satues evidence
story: If you remove the evidence you remove the deed.These statues are our history — for both black and white people — so removing them is tampering with the past.Slave traders Edward Colston and Robert Milligan, whose statues have been torn down, are part of black history, which is part of British history.I was born in Jamaica and came to Britain aged  in .People have tried to exclude me but Jamaica has been part of the British story since .I object to the fact that someone would say I’ve got no British connections.I’ve had a long career in academia specialising in the science of brewing and in  became the first black professor in Scotland.I’ve achieved six doctorates and been knighted.Today I’m Jamaica’s Honorary Consul in Scotland.I’m an example of what can be achieved with good people around you and a bit of luck.But I don’t think people’s lives should be dependent on luck.We have prejudices in society that limit representation, education and opportunities for black people.Last year I arrived in Edinburgh to give a lecture and the attendant at the door said: “What do you want ”I said: “l’ve come to give a lecture.” She replied: “When ”I said: “pm.’ She said: “You can’t be because the lecture then is being given by Professor Sir Geoff Palmer.”She’d never seen black people with any status. It’s the system which hasn’t educated her.I don’t think that will change by pulling statues down. You might have made yourself feel better but that’s it.I think in  or  years when black people look back they will realise that part of their history was removed.And white racists don’t mind as it helps people forget slavery.I don’t want people to take my view without asking me because that’s what we’re complaining about with Black Lives Matter.How many people were asked about these actions I have been helping with a plaque for the Melville Monument in St Andrew Square, Edinburgh, which has a statue of Henry Dundas on top.Dundas was a politician who obstructed the abolition of slavery by  years, which meant another , Africans were enslaved.I want to put that under his name.I was on the committee that put up a statue of Mary Seacole in the grounds of St Thomas’ Hospital opposite the House of Commons in London.Mary was a Jamaican-born nurse who cared for British soldiers during the th century Crimean War.London Mayor Sadiq Khan has asked for a review into the city’s statues.I would much rather a committee on removing deprivation.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: michael schumacher stem cell operation
story: French cardiologist Dr Philippe Menasche, who is known to have operated on the Formula One racing legend, , before, will perform a pioneering heart op on the German, Italian media reports.French newspaper Le Dauphine reports the latest procedure could take place in the next few days.In , Schumacher suffered a head injury when skiing off-piste in the resort of Meribel in the French Alps.However, his condition has been shrouded in secrecy as he is treated privately by a team of doctors at his home in Geneva, Switzerland.Yet, according to Dr Nicola Acciari, a top neurosurgeon, Schumacher is suffering from osteoporosis and muscle atrophy caused by his lack of movement since his accident.He said: The goal is to regenerate Michaels nervous system.Dr Menasche, who is known as a “pioneer in stem cell surgery”, is reportedly going to carry out another stem cell op on the racing drivers heart.But, the exact details of the procedure are unknown and the Frenchmans techniques have been called mysterious.According to Spanish outlet minutos, Menasche is using surgery to transfer stem cells from the Germans heart to his brain. In stem cell therapy, cells are taken from either bone marrow or the patients own heart and injected into other parts of the body in order to repair damaged tissue.Schumacher, who won a record seven F world championships with Benetton and Ferrari, underwent his first stem-cell therapy in Paris in September last year.French journalist Jean-Michel Décugis told The Times that the stem cell therapy will have an anti-inflammatory effect which will mostly likely impact the brain. He said: Our sources say that Michael Schumacher is receiving stem cell perfusions that... produce a systemic anti-inflammatory effect.That is to say they reach the whole body and you could imagine that they reach Michael Schumachers brain.Its quite mysterious. Officially [Menasché] works only on the heart.Stem cell therapy - also known as regenerative medicine - promotes the repair of diseased, injured and dysal tissues.Stem cells are the bodys raw materials - the cells from which all specialised cells, like brain or heart cells, are generated.Under lab conditions stem cells can ide to create daughter cells.These daughter cells can form new specialised cells with a specic- brain, heart muscle, blood or bone cells.The pioneering treatment is still relatively new and many studies are examining its potential.In Michael Schumachers case its understood doctors are aiming to use the treatment to regenerate his nervous system, which includes the brain and spinal cord.It could involve scientists taking stem cells from the Formula One legends bone marrow, to create new brain and spinal cord cells with an aim of treating those that were injured in his accidentHe is carrying out experiments with [secretome] that is made by a laboratory from new stem cells and injected into veins, until now only on animals.Mr Décugis also claims that Schumacher is being injected with secretome -protein found in the human body - which he says Menasche calls stem cell juice.In October, Menasche warned fans that he does not work miracles following the first widely-reported stem cell therapy on the sports star.He also slammed claims he was carrying out experiments on the legendary racing driver.Speaking with Italian newspaper La Republica, he said: I do not perform miracles.My team and I are not doing an experiment, an abominable term that is not in line with a serious medical view.And after the procedure last year, a nurse told Le Parisien that Schumacher was conscious.She said: Yes he is in my service ... And I can assure you that he is conscious.Speaking about the cutting-edge procedure, Acciari said: Over the past  years, science has made enormous progress with stem cell treatment.But that does not change that we still do not know much about the human brain.We are not able to say what the results will be.In January, Italian brain surgeon Nicola Acciari - who has not reportedly treated the German - claims he will still be changed from the man his millions of fans remember.We must imagine a person very dferent from the one we remember on the track, with a very altered and deteriorated organic, muscular and skeletal structure, said Acciari.All as a result of the brain trauma he suffered, he told Italian newspaper Contro Copertina.Last month, former Ferrari driver Felipe Massa said he is very close to Schumacher and said his situation is not easy.He told Fox Brazil: I know how heis, I have information. My relationship with him has always been very close.It is less close with his we Corinna because she did not go to many races. But I think the main thing about all this is that we know that his situation is not easy. He is in a dficult phase but we need to respect him and the family.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman makes home unsellable after 30 years decorating and youll see why
story: Mary Rose Young, , has been painting her home in Lydney, Gloucestershire in bright colours by hand since .She bought the two cottages - once lived in by squatters - for just £,, and after years of pain-staking renovations she decided to sellin .Real estate agents told her the home should be worth at least £,, but its eccentric style meant it has failed to drum up any serious interest.Only one curious person was persuaded to view the house and they chose not to buy.Ms Young hoped to sell the home to open up a boutique bed and breakfast nearby.The cottage is full of vivid colours, including striking yellow and green walls, black and white tiled floors, a zebra-patterned toilet seat and bright pink furnishings - the same colour as Ms Youngs hair.She shares the house with her musician husband, Phil Butcher, .Despite a lack of buying interest Ms Young refuses to change the style of her home.“I love my house and the house really works for me. I’m a colourful person and I even have pink hair. I like it more and more as I get older, she said.“I made this house around my own le and I wasn’t thinking about it being sellable.“We’re living like two children in a doll’s house and in retrospect why would anybody  want to buy it “I just thought it might go to a mad collector of my work who might want to buy it, but no one was interested.Ms Young said she enjoyed transforming the property from two rundown cottages into a colourful playhouse for adults. “It became a really fun project for me on the side of my pottery business and I was so galvanised by it I ended up neglecting my pottery at times.“I painted it all myself and I would get help for some bitsI was in a hurry and was trying to work on the pottery. When you do it by yourself, you do it with all your heart.“I’ve stopped noticing how colourful it is because I’ve lived here for so long.“Lots of people are self-conscious and don’t say much when they see the decoration, but the right reaction is to laugh and go ‘oh wow.’“It should make you feel like a child walking into a sweet shop. I want people to feel like adults can have lots of fun too.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kids schools february winter changes r number
story: Earlier this week the Government dropped plans for all primary school kids to go back for a month before the summer.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesInstead its now the aim for all kids - both primary and secondary - toby September for the start of the new academic year.Boris Johnson said yesterday its his ambition to get all children back in the classrooms.But the rate of infection was not yet low enough to get everyone in.Class sizes have been capped at and will prove a limitation to getting more kids in.However, earlier this week Matt Hancock admitted it was still uncertain they will be able to go back for September as planned.The Health Secretary signalled pupils might be stuck at home for months to come, with secondary schools reopening in September at the earliest”.And one official at the heart of coronavirus-making policy told The Spectator that the fearedschools were not opened by September then they could be pushed back into next year: If Sage are this cautious going into summer, then they are not going to want to play fast and loose with the R number heading into winter.Education Select Committee chair Robert Halfon told The Sun: We have to get these children learning again.If schools dont open in September, we will have an ice age in terms of childrens learning.There will always be a reason not to open schools, butit’s not impossible, theres a way to do it.And former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith said: “If we don’t make the change from two metres to one metre we simply will not be able to get the schools open and operating properly in September, which will be an absolute disaster for children and their education.And we won’t be able to get people back to work and to work properly in all areas because of public transport and hospitality.They simply cannot and will not work at two metres. It is a big decision the Government has got to make and make it now.Today No said that the Nightingale hospitals would be kept for the meantime, amid fears of a renewed wave of the virus over the winer.The Prime Ministers official spokesman said the hospitals remained an important surge capacity.We may still need Nightingale hospitals for the months ahead. We will maintain that extra capacity until such time as there is more certainty, the spokesman added.Yesterday, Government scientists revealed their fears of a deadly second wave in the winter which could throw a spanner in the works to kids education and the wider recovery,Sir Patrick said last night that scientists were looking carefully at how lockdown was managed should this happen again in the winter.Professor Whitty said: We have to accept that we could find ourselves in one of three situations.One is where we have a situation wherestarts to escape control.The aim is that wevery slowly to prevent that from happening but thats the risk.The second situation isand we all think there is a a reasonable chance that in the winter this virus will have some advantages it doesnt have the rest of the year.Its something that transmits more easily indoors.Therefore, things that are working well in summer and autumn may cease to be working as well in winter.The nature of new epidemics is very often they come in waves, circling around the world andwe get hit by another wave.At that point we need to understand better what is the optimal mix of things we can do.One of the Governments key tests for lting lockdown is ensuring the NHS will be able to cope - but as the nights start to draw in and more people fall ill with regular winter viruses, the health service could start to falter again.Today No said again that the threat level for the virus had not reduced down from four to three as was predicted.Some moves to ease the lockdown have been made - story: William Callaghan went missing on Monday while hiking with his family on Mount Disappointment in Victoria, Australia.The disappearance prompted urgent fears for Williams safety, with nighttime temperatures in the area currently below freezing. A manhunt involving more than  people was launched, and yesterday the teen was found alive and well.Mum Penny said her son probably thought the whole incident was a bit of an adventure, while a child psychologist has said it could be his condition that helped him survive. Speaking to news.au, Professor Robyn Young of Flinders University said: “His autism meant he was at risk because he wasn’t responding by name and he was upset by helicopters flying overhead.But at the same time there were a number of things that were protecting him.“Much of them relate to hypersensitivity and hyposensitivity – basically they have a high pain threshold.“We’re not surethey don’t feel it or don’t respond to it but I’ve seen kids that have walked around with broken bones.”She added that William probably didnt feel the cold as much as another child would have. As part of the hunt, emergency responders played the theme tune from Thomas the Tank Engine, Williams favourite TV show, over a PA system. He was eventually found by volunteer Ben Gibbs almost  hours after last being seen.I was wandering through the bush, and it was quite thick so I was breaking my way through it, said Gibbs. And then he was just about  meters from me standing there, just really angelic.Speaking to local media shortly after the discovery, Penny Callaghan said: Im obviously immensely relieved. I am really overwhelmed. Hes well as can be expected in the circumstances.She said today that William slept well last night and is in good spirits. title: weather maps predict next wave coronavirus
story: In the study, researchers found that areas affected early on in the outbreak were on a similar band of northern latitude such as Wuhan in Asia, Paris in Europe and Seattle in the US.⚠️ Read our Japan and Wuhan, China and were compared to  cities that had smaller numbers of virus cases.“Substantial” was defined as a country reporting at least  deaths from COVID- by March . From November  to time. Researchers then looked at the temperature near the Earths surface, where the majority of human activity takes place.Results showed that in Wuhan in January and in February in the other seven cities, the average temperature at airport weather stations was between Fand F . Average temperatures  to  days before the first death in each city were roughly the same, ranging from Fto F .The cities also had similar low amounts of humidity.“All the temperatures for the eight locations being in such a close range was a little surprising,” Dr Mohammad Sajadi, an associate professor at the Institute of Human Virology at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, told DailyMail.  “I was not expecting the temperatures to be so close and the humidity ranges to be so close.”Cold Time is of the essence during these critical summer months.”Greg Clark, head of the Commons Science Committee, said the Government’s “unquestioned default” of two metres was called into question by more countries going for the one-metre margin.The former Business Secretary said: “We should be using our knowledge to constantly question whether this is right and have the courage to be able to changethe evidence recommends that.”Many countries have adopted the one-metre World Health Organisation recommendation.Germany operates . metres and risk-averse Japan at . metres. It makes the UK one of the most cautious countries.The PM has said the number of coronavirus cases was still too high to reduce social distancing.  Ministers warned last night that millions of children might notto school until next year unless distance rules are eased.Earlier this week, the Government dropped plans for all primary school children to go back for a month before the summer.And the PM has said September is now only his “ambition” because the number of infections is still too high to increase maximum class sizes of , or to relax the two-metre rule.Chief medical officer Professor Chris Whitty has warned that a winter spike in coronavirus cases could trigger a second lockdown.This has sparked fears that the Government’s scientic advisory body SAGE will not change its advice on social distancing in schools before the winter.And that will make it impossible for schools to operate anywhere near full capacity.One government insider saidSAGE were so cautious going into summer they would not want to be playing “fast and loose” with the “R” infection rate heading into winter.Boss of the Commons Education committee Robert Halfon told The Sun: “There’s always going to be a reason not to open schools but we have to get our kids learning again. People may be worried about a second wave butschools don’t open in September, we will have an ice age in terms of children’s learning.”Former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith said Mr Johnson should have the courage to make the “big decision”.He told The Sun: “Unless you get this down to one metre, you’ll not get schools back because they can’t work at two metres.“Public transport doesn’t work, businesses can’t work, the hospitality sector won’t work.“At the apex of every strategic decision lies two metres. You cannot get people back to school or work unless we change the rule.” Infectious disease expert Professor Mark Woolhouse said the PM was being too cautious and claimed that it was “fine” to reduce social distancing.He said the PM must not let the two-metre rule become “set in stone” and urged him to listen to the latest scientic evidence.He said: “I understand the reasons for caution and I completely respect it but I think as the evidence accumulates those reasons become less convincing.“What I’m hearing is going down to one metre would make a very, very big dference to large parts of the economy and to education as well as for schools. It’s easy to see why. So what government has to do, based on the evidence available, is to say, ‘Well, is that increased risk, however slight, worth taking ’“Government is being in my view very, very cautious.“What I’d like to see is a continual willingness to reappraise decisions about lockdown based on accumulating evidence.“This is a new virus, we’re all understanding it better, almost literally day by day.“So we have to be responsive to the changes in evidence andwe do that I expect we’ll find, as many countries around the world have, that one metre is fine.”To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: solve rubiks cube puzzle step by step
story: Originally called Magic Cube, the combination puzzle made its debut in American toy stores in May of , sparking a national trend.The toy is still popular with people of all ages - Rubiks Cube retail sales hit  million in , its biggest year since the craze of the s, a company spokesperson told Inc.Still stumped on how to solve the brainteaser  Heres a step-by-step guide on how to master the popular puzzle.The first thing youll want to do is create the daisy, which is a yellow square at the center of the cube surrounded by four white squares.This may take a few tries - as youre creating the daisy, think about the necessary steps to take in order to create it.On one of the cubes side faces, line up the top middle color with the center color.Once youve lined up the colors, turn the entire face twice so that it faces upside-down.Repeat this step for all four sides - when you do, there should be a white cross on the bottom face of the cube.Continue to hold the cube with the white side face down.To solve the bottom row, focus on the white squares on the top layer of the cube.Depending on the side the white square is on, perform a trick by rotating the left or right face of the cube and repeat this step until all of the squares are on the bottom.To complete a right trick, rotate the right face clockwise, then the top face clockwise, and the right face counterclockwise.For a left trick, turn the left face counterclockwise, then the top face counterclockwise, and the left face clockwise.Youre halfway there! Now its time to focus on the second row of squares.Rotate the cubes top layer until an upside-down T of all one color forms - make sure there isnt a yellow square in the middle of the bottom row on the top face. The color of this square will correspond with either the right or left face of the cube.If the square corresponds with the right face, rotate the top clockwise by performing a right trick.If the square correlates to the left face, rotate the top face counterclockwise and perform a left trick.Youll have moved around a white square while doing a trick - replace the white square in the same way we did in Step , and repeat this until the second row of the cube is complete.Create a yellow cross on the top of the cube by moving the front face clockwise, the top face clockwise, then the right face clockwise.Next, turn the top face counterclockwise, right face counterclockwise, and then the front face counterclockwise.The next step is to align the middle square colors of the top layer in the correct position.Three of the top layer colors will move counterclockwise, while the colored square that will stay in place is the color facing you.Turn the right face clockwise, top face clockwise, right face counterclockwise, top face clockwise, and right face clockwise.Then, turn the top face clockwise twice before turning the right face counterclockwise.Youre almost done! But first, youll have to make sure the corners are in the right place.For this next move, all of the corners will move away from the corner closest to your left.Turn the right face clockwise, top face counterclockwise, left face clockwise, and the top face clockwise.After that, turn the right face counterclockwise, the top face counterclockwise, and the left face clockwise before turning the top face clockwise.Repeat as necessary until the corners are in the correct place, although they may be rotated incorrectly.Rotate the corners so that the colored squares are on the correct face.Do this by turning the right face counterclockwise, the bottom face counterclockwise, right face clockwise, and the bottom face clockwise.Repeat these steps until the yellow square is in the correct place at the top of the cube.Then you can rotate the top face and perform the same move to place all of the corners in the proper position.Congratulations, youve just completed a Rubiks cube!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cop horse bolted pride thin blue line
story: Brave Wpc Nicky Vernon said she was ‘’just about hanging in there’’ following her fall - but urged colleagues to keep holding the line until she is back to work.The cop also posted photos of her horse ‘Rocky the Rockstar’ enjoying himself in a field after his traumatic experience last weekend.He reared up and bolted when thugs hurled missiles at mounted cops after a Black Lives Matter protest last Saturday evening in Westminster, Central London.Mum-of-one Nicky was knocked backwards off Rocky when she collided with a traffic light on Whitehall.She suffered a punctured lung and fractured collar bone and ribs in the fall and was rescued by colleagues from the Met’s Tactical Support Group as a baying mob surrounded her.Meanwhile, Rocky galloped away from the violence and made his way to his nearby stables at Great Scotland Yard.Initially, it was feared that Nicky’s le was in peril and her husband James - also a mounted Met officer - was alerted.She was taken to St Mary’s Hospital, Paddington, where she is recovering, although her family have been unable to visit because of the coronavirus risk.Nicky said she and Rocky have been inundated with messages from well-wishers.She wrote on her Facebook page yesterday: ‘’I’ve had a few enquiries as to how we are.‘’As you can see PH Rocky the Rockstar is doing just great and is getting some well deserved downtime.‘’I’m just about hanging in there with the outpouring of love and support from my family, friends and even strangers keeping me going.’’She went on: ‘’It’s humbling to receive such support and a constant reminder of the strength of that blue line.‘’For some reason it’s referred to as ‘thin’ but it seems it’s made from something stronger than you can imagine.‘’Just unbreakable. Hold it for me until I get back.’’She signed off the message with three blue hearts, saying : ‘’Thank you everyone‘’A JustGiving page set up to raise a few hundred pounds for the officer has now reached £,.It is understood the funds raised will go to a police charity.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The Canadian stylist, who has apologized for her behavior towards Toronto-based internet star Sasha Exeter, has now been fired by Bell Media and CTV who have pulled her bridal show, I Do, Redo, claiming the host had conflicted with their commitment to ersity and equality.In a staggering show of support, they tweeted just hours after The Sun first broke the story, saying: Bell Media and CTV encourages our entire team including on-air talent to practice respect, inclusivity and allyship as we pledge to work better and more openly to listen to and amply black voices, and not minimize them, the statement began.Sasha bravely spoke out in an emotional video on Wednesday night, saying Meghans best friend had taken offence to a very generic call to action posted on Instagram, feeling it was directly aimed at her.She stated: Jessica never wanted to stand up and use her voice in the first place and didnt understand why she needed to.This I found quite strange seeing that she is very vocal about supporting many causes and very open about everything  so how could she not be speaking up about this issue affecting everyone in the world.Also her best friend is arguably one of the most famous black women in the world... You think your voice matters. Well it only mattersyou express it with kindness and without shaming people who are simply trying to learn. Good luck.She said she felt Mulroney was threatening her livelihood but felt like a fraud for not speaking out publicly about the row.Jessica wrote: I am unequivocally sorry for not doing that with you, and for any hurt I caused.As I told you privately, I have lived a very public and personal experience with my closest friend where race was front and centre. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Conservative councillor has apologised after sharing racist comments on social media following the wave of Black Lives Matter protests across the world sparked by the death of George Floyd in the US.Debbie Young, a Tory on Stroud District Council, retweeted a post from far-right media commentator Katie Hopkins and another from a US-based Donald Trump supporter branding protesters anti-fascist terrorists. Hopkins had commented on Twitter about protests in London, saying the sad truth is that the real Minority Ethnic in London is White Brits.Ms Young also shared a post which suggested protesters were bone idle and the mindless thugsapos solution. Copies of the posts, which have since been deleted, were passed to the PA news agency. In a statement posted on Twitter, Ms Young said she sincerely apologised for any offence caused. She wrote: On June  in response to the mass protests taking place as a result of the tragic death of George Floyd, I used social media to promote equality. I stated that all lives matter and that I had never taken race into account.At the same time, I said I understood there was anger following George Floydaposs tragic death, but urged protests involving large numbers of people to stop in order to avoid spreading coronavirus, highlighting the need to maintain social distancing.My concern was for peopleaposs safety due to the potential spread of coronavirus.  Some of the protests escalated into violence on June  and I re-tweeted comments made by two iniduals. I accept that in doing so I may have caused concern and upset by my comments and in re-tweeting these posts. This was never my intention. I sincerely apologise for any offence caused. This was no way in indication of support for the views of those iniduals. Neither was it a reflection of my values or my long-held beliefs on equality. I abhor racism in any form. I have worked tirelessly throughout my le to promote equality and to oppose racism. I have always served my community to the best of my ability, treating everyone equally and without prejudice. I will continue to fight against racism and to promote equality in all our communities. In a statement, a Conservative Party spokesman said: We are investigating this matter.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA group of family members of coronavirus victims have demanded an immediate public inquiry into the crisis.The Covid- Bereaved Families for Justice UK group, which consists of  relatives of people who have died during the pandemic, has told the BBC an urgent review was necessary to limit the ongoing effects of the coronavirus crisis and prevent more deaths.The groupaposs lawyer Elkan Abrahamson told the broadcaster an early inquiry should be held prior to any complete formal proceeding, which is expected to take place once the pandemic is over. What we need to look at straightaway are the issues which are le-and-death decisions, he said. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE.   We expect there will be a second spike. We want to know what the Government is going to do when that happens. Mr Abrahamson said action now could also help solidy government plans for fully reopening schools in September and further easing the lockdown, as well as aposlay outapos crucial scientic advice for decision making. The call comes in light of a National Audit Office report, which shows how many of the , patients discharged from hospitals into care homes at the peak of the outbreak were infected with Covid- remains unknown.  Jamie Brownaposs dad Tony died of the virus in Colchester General Hospital on March , less than three weeks after taking a train into central London - something he does regularly. The grieving son, part of the campaign group, has slammed the government for locking down the country too late. The -year-old told the BBC: I canapost help but believe thatweaposd entered lockdown sooner he wouldnapost have been exposed in the way he was, he said.  Tony, , developed a dry cough and temperature before appearing to be on the road to recovery when he was struck down by chest pains the day before he died. Jamie saidthe government had urged people to see a doctor early enough his dad - who was trying to wait it out at home - could still be alive. The groupaposs request comes after Scotlandaposs former chief scientic adviser Professor Dame Anne Glover said an inquiry must be held now because a second wave could come at the same time as winter flu - meaning hospitals could become overrun. Prof Glover, who is now president of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, said: Given that second wave is likely to come at a time that is likely to coincide with seasonal influenza, and that would give us serious problems, we really need to understand what the failings have been in our apparent inability to be able to deal with this pandemic appropriately.  Where failures have happened, [we need to understand] why have the failures happened and how can we avoid those failures in the future. This inquiry needs to be delivering in a matter of months, not a matter of years, because the purpose of it is to ensure we do not make the same mistakes should we get a second wave of the virus.

story: NewsHero dad who used baseball bat to shield police officer during attack had to actFootage of the incident in Hackney, East London, showed the man, identied as Kemran, attempt to shield the officer on the ground as youths tried to punch and kick him on WednesdayShareByDave Burke:,  JUN NewsThe hero dad, named Kemran, rushed out with a baseball bat to try and dfuse the incident" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters.
