title: new-musselburgh-racecourse-operators-hope-take-return-racing-month
story: The racecourse hopes to see aof racing, behind closed doors, at the end of the month with back to back fixtures proposed on June  and July .And at a online video call meeting on Tuesday of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee , which oversees the racecourse, it was revealed new operator Chester Racing Company hopes to be in place before the first date.East Lothian Councils legal adviser Carlo Grilli said negotiations over the takeover were ongoing but it was hoped Chester would be in place later this month.He said: "Given the end of June has a potential fixture the proposal for Chester would be to take over a few days prior to the end of June to get a few days prior in."East Lothian Council has been negotiating with Chester after it was named the preferred bidders for a contract to operate the course last year.The course, which sits on common good land, had previously been run by a governance committee made up of elected councillors and representatives of Lothians Racing Syndicate ndash originally Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee and more recently MRAC.The decision to bring in a third party operator came after the British Horseracing Authority threatened to remove Musselburghrsquos racing licence when relations between the members of the previous committee became toxic one-month extensions were put in place to allow the new operator to come in.Last month the BHA extended the licence until the end of October.Councillor Fiona ODonnell, MRAC chairperson, said she and fellow members had held talks with Chester over their involvement in the town in the future.She said: "It says a lot about Musselburgh that they are still very keen. Chester have some really positive intentions in terms of the local community as well and this is good news."Councillor Stuart Currie, MRAC member, welcomed news Chester was still keen to take over, pointing out the council could have been back to "square one"they had taken a step back during the Covid- crisis.He said: "That Chester is still taking over the running of the race course is really positive. It could have been the case that some people might have turned around and said they did not want to do anything right now and we would have been back at square one."It is important for the racing industry and it is important for the staff at Musselburgh."The committee which met via Skype chose to hear a health and safety report and report by the racecourse general manager in private citing commercial reasons for not discussing them in public.

title: small-car-parks-reopen-locals
story: Most of the local authoritys coastal car parks remain closed as it tries to deter daytrippers from heading to East Lothian.However, smaller rural car parks and a few of the more remote coastal car parks have been reopened.The local authoritydecided to reopen some of the facilities quietly and "without fanfare" as it aimed to keep visitors local.Public toilets and childrenrsquos play areas remain closed and Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesman, appealed to people to stay within their local areas.He said:ldquoIn line with Scottish Government guidance, we have decided to proceed with a partial re-opening of car parks ndash focused on smaller coastal and inland countryside parking sites."This will provide local residents, particularly those who are less mobile and may have dficulty accessing the countryside by foot or bike, with more access to the coast or countryside for leisure and exercise.ldquoWe do understand why people from other areas wanted to visit our beautul coast and beaches during the recent spell of warm weather. But progress in tackling Covid- remains fragile."Therefore, given the need to reduce the risk of popular beauty spots becoming crowded and potentially unsafe, our larger coastal car parks will remain closed at this time.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming visitors from further afield to these sites and where in East Lothian when it is safe to do so but at the moment we would ask that people do not travel to beauty spots from out with their local area."Car parks now open for local residents at coastal sites are:Back Sands and Mountjoy, Fisherrow, MusselburghLevenhall Links, MusselburghMorrisonrsquos Haven, Prestongrange, and Prestongrange Mining MuseumPreston Links Sailing Club, PrestonpansPond Hall, on The Promenade, Port Seton North Berwick East BeachLinkfield, John Muir Country Park Shore Road, West BarnsWhite SandsBarns NessSkaterawThorntonloch.Inland car parks now open are:Butterdean, near GladsmuirWoodhall, near PencaitlandTraprain LawPencraig, both near East LintonHopetoun , north of Haddington andPencaitland Railway Walk.

title: pies-gravy-power-vegan-shroomballs-urgently-recalled-supermarkets
story: Heres a round-up of the latest product recalls.Sainsburys are recalling a product from their vegan range over fears that it may contain plastic.Plant Pioneers Vegan Shroomballs have been recalled due to the potential presence of "small pieces of white plastic" which would make the product unsafe to eat.Sainsburys released a statement saying that no other products had been affected by the contamination.It said: "It has been brought to our attention that the above product may potentially contain small pieces of white plastic."We are asking customers who have purchased this product toit to their nearest Sainsburys store for a full refund when they next visit for groceries  other essentials."Food Standards Agency advise that those who are in possession of the product shouldit to the store from where it was brought next time they visit for essential shopping.Those who are vulnerable or shielding have been advised by Sainsburys to call its careline on   or by email to customer.service@sainsburysThe product details are as follows:Name: Plant Pioneers Vegan ShroomballsSize: gUse by date: All dates between June  and ,Fryrsquos Family Foods haverecalled Fryrsquos Mushroom Country Style Pie because it contains milk which is not mentioned on the label.The recall means the product is a possible health risk for anyone with an allergy or intolerance to milk or milk constituents.Frys said: "Due to a packaging error, some boxes contain chicken and ham pie, which is also not suitable for people avoiding the consumption of meat. The affected product has only been sold in Sainsburyrsquos stores."The Food Standards Agency added: "If you have bought the above product and have an allergy or intolerance to milk or milk constituents, or avoid the consumption of meat, do not eat it."Insteadit to the store from where it was bought for a full refund when next visiting for groceries and other essentials."Alternatively contact Fryrsquos Family Foods UK on   or by email to enquiries@frysfamilyfoods"The product details are as follows:Name:Fryrsquos Mushroom Country Style PieSize: gUse by date: June , Allergens: MilkPremier Foods have recalledBisto Original Gravy Powder because it contains milk which is not mentioned on the label.This means the product is a possible health risk for anyone with an allergy or intolerance to milk or milk constituents.This only affects products sold in certain Asda stores in the north of England with lot number  A and time codes between : and :.Those who have bought the product and have an allergy or intolerance to milk or milk constituents should not eat it.Customers making an essential trip to the store where it was bought fromcanthe item in-store for a full refund.Alternatively, shoppers can contact Premier Foods Customer Service at www.bisto or call    , or call Asda Customer Relations on   .The product details are as follows:Name:Bisto Original Gravy PowderSize: gLot number:  A Use by date: End of March Allergens: Milk

title: east-lothian-mp-quizzes-prime-minister-food-standards
story: Mr MacAskill quizzed Boris Johnston during a virtual Prime Ministers Questions over what would be done to protect current animal welfare and food standards.And he accused the UK Government of failing to "enshrine protections in the agriculture bill".Referring to another of the ongoing debates around a future trade deal with the USA, Mr MacAskill asked the Prime Minister to make an assurance ldquothat we wonrsquot face chlorinated chicken on our table, along with Kentucky-fried medicine in our hospitals.Mr MacAskill called on the Prime Minister to be clear that high standards must be protected and to establish a commission to look at food standards.He said: "I have had a number of constituents contacting me recently to express signicant concerns about the UK Governmentrsquos trade policy." It is clear that food standards, animal welfare, and environmental concerns are not a priority for this government who seem to be more interested in getting any trade deal done to prove a point about Brexit, rather than for the benefit of the people of these islands."The long-awaited Brexit benefits are receding further into the distance every week and the future under an American Trade deal looks grim indeed for the sector and citizens.Last month Minette Batters, the president of the National Farmerrsquos Union ,said: ldquoOur trade policy must reflect our moral responsibilities to the planet and the people and creatures that live on it ndash protecting our natural environment, caring for our farmed animals, and working toward a more sustainable, climate-friendly way of farming and food production. These are issues that cannot be wished away or presumed dealt with by brief pledges in a manesto or verbal assurances in media interviews.Mr Johnson responded to Mr MacAskills question,saying ldquoon leaving the EU, as we have, we will be able to increase our animal welfare standards.

title: countys-slavery-links-highlighted
story: Leading human rights campaigner Sir Geoff Palmer, Professor Emeritus in the School of Le Sciences at Heriot-Watt University, Edinburgh, highlighted James Wedderburn, a plantation and slave owner who lived in Inveresk Lodge, near Musselburgh, saying that James and his brother John went to Jamaica after their dad was hanged.They both stayed there for a number of years, buying land and slaves before ing to Scotland in the s. On Jamesrsquoshe bought and moved into Inveresk Lodge, marrying into the Colville family. His daughter also later married Lord Selkirk. James and his we are buried in Inveresk churchyard.Sir Geoff said: ldquoThatrsquos very important. He went to Jamaica after his father was hanged, they had no money, they came back, he buys the Lodge and his daughter marries into British aristocracy. They came back from Jamaica, where they made a lot of money and made a name for themselves, his daughter married into the Scottish aristocracy. The fact is that itrsquos a good story and itrsquos important, and itrsquos why street names are important.There are streets in Inveresk named after the Wedderburn family, such as Wedderburn Court and Wedderburn Terrace.When askedthese street names should be changed, Sir Geoff said: ldquoYou let people know information about the name and that these streets were, for example, named after this family who were slave owners and lived nearby.He added that plaques could be placed next to such street signs, alerting and educating people on the history behind the name, something that could be beneficial to future generations.Sir Geoff noted the important role stories like these played in East Lothian history. He said: ldquoItrsquos an important part of East Lothian and Inveresk history andyou remove that or rename it and call it something , you could be removing part of the history of East Lothian.ldquoSome of the street names, I donrsquot want them removed.ldquoBy removing them you are removing the deed, andyou remove the deed people are not going to be aware in the future and then history could be dferent. If you change a bit of the street name, a bit of history is then missing.ldquoWe need to address the issues black people have and the issues that cause their lives to be dficult rather than changing statues. You need to address the social issues and the disparity.He added that history like this should be included in the curriculum and taught in schools.When askedthere were any statues or works of art in East Lothian which they were reviewing following the BLM movement and demonstrations, a spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe views of local communities about who should be celebrated in their towns and villages is extremely important and East Lothian Council will listen to any concerns expressed on these matters.Parts and people of East Lothian with links to the slave trade are highlighted on the website: www.ucl.ac.uk lbs maps britain

title: east-lothian-not-immume-racism-demonstrations-held
story: In North Berwick on Sunday, more than  people joineda peaceful protest, ensuring they were two metres apart in line with social distancing.And in Musselburgh, the townrsquos archer sculpture was dressed to support the cause while Black Lives Mattersigns were erected at Memorial Park, Haddington, though later vandalised.The demonstrations in East Lothian and throughout the world follow the death of George Floyd, in Minneapolis, after a police officer knelt on his neck for almost nine minutes.Seventeen-year-olds Abbie Greenwood and Maya Chukwuma organised a well-attended BLM gathering close to North Berwickrsquos East Beach.Abbie said: ldquoWe just wanted to show our support even for a small town, and to spread awareness to the local community.Grandmother Alexandra Graham, from North Berwick, said: ldquoI was delighted to join the protest and I want to laud the young people who put it together."Like many others, I couldnrsquot get through to the protest in Edinburgh because of the lockdown, but making a stand matters to me very much."My young granddaughter will face racismand discrimination in the future so I donrsquot just want to be in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement, Irsquom also trying to learn how best to support my granddaughter as she grows.Meanwhile, in Haddington, BLM signs were placed outside the townrsquos Memorial Park.Phoebe Hayman, who lives in the town, was joined by friends in putting up the signs, which had messages including: ldquoIt is not enough to be non-racist be anti-racist and ldquoBlack Lives Matter.The -year-old, studying politics and French at the University of Glasgow, said: ldquoWe feel really passionate that this is an issue that affects everyone and all communities.ldquoWe wanted to go to the protest in Edinburgh but, due to Covid, a lot of people have key workers living with them or vulnerable people and it was not worth the risk.ldquoWe decided to do something that people will see and maybe make them think.However, the posters, which were put up at the park, at the junction of Court Street, Station Road, Hope Park and Knox Place, did not win the approval of everyone.Phoebe added: ldquoWhen we put them up, someone drove past and booed, which is horric.Similarly, white spray paint was used to cover two of the posters, with the words ldquowightdoes towritten over ldquoBlack Lives Matterrsquo.Phoebe and friends have also received a number of messages from people showing their appreciation for the efforts. The signs have been repainted.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, who represents the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, said: ldquoIt was the issue of racism and its corrosive impact on society which first got me interested and involved in politics as a young person growing up in Scotland.ldquoIt remains a blight on our society and the Black Lives Matter campaign rightly highlights that.ldquoSadly, racism certainly exists in East Lothian and as a councillor Irsquove supported businesses, families and young people who have experienced racist incidents.ldquoThere is still a long way to go to tackle this endemic problem which we all have a responsibility to help confront and address.For centuries racism has been a systemic problem in Scotland and the rest of the UK, acknowledged Iain Gray, MSP for East Lothian.He said: ldquoThis ingrained prejudice still blights the lives of non-white people across our country today.ldquoIt can be seen in all aspects of le, from education and employment opportunities, to our legal and political systems.ldquoThe latest example of this is the growing body of evidence pointing to the fact that the socio-economic factors at play in the lives of many black and minority ethnic people make them more at risk from dying of coronavirus.ldquoWhile East Lothian is generally a welcoming and inclusive area, we are not immune from the effects of this institutional racism and discrimination and there have certainly been racist incidents here over the years.ldquoEvery community can always do more to combat and campaign against all forms of racism, including anti-semitism and Islamophobia, which is why I support peaceful and responsible protests which observe public health rules by Black Lives Matter campaigners.ldquoI was very sorry to hear that BLM signs in Haddington had been vandalised ndash a sign that we still have a long way to go on this issue.County MP Kenny MacAskill said that what was unfolding in America was ldquotragic and frightening but an organised challenge to the racism shown there had been a long time coming."Throughout the sweep of history we see that certain moments acted as flash points, he said."The murder of George Floyd seems to have been one such flash point in the US.ldquoAt the same time, the global spread of the Black Lives Matter movement has shown that no country is immune to racism.ldquoScotland is no dferent and laws require enforced and attitudes need challenged.ldquoThe vandalism of peaceful protestersrsquo signs in Haddington was shameful but doesnrsquot reflect the views of the overwhelming majority of East Lothian citizens.ldquoAs I understand it, all the protesting in the county was done peacefully, and with propersocial distancing."Therersquos much more to be done and efforts need to be renewed as challenges will grow post lockdown, but Irsquom sure folk in East Lothian will continue to speak out against injustice and racism wherever it happens and I will be with them, helping to ensure that steps are taken to address racism and inequality wherever it is found.Councillor Willie Innes, East Lothian Council leader, said: ldquoBlack Lives Matter is a global movement highlighting the discrimination, inequalities and violence experienced by black communities in many western societies.ldquoRecent events in the USA have resulted in iniduals and groups collectively lending their support to building more inclusive communities and tackling racial discrimination in all of its forms.ldquoI believe East Lothian to be a welcoming county but each of us need to reflect on how best we can challenge racial discrimination within our own communities and work places.Foysol Choudhury, chair of the Edinburgh and Lothians Regional Equality Council , said they as an organisation condemned all forms of discrimination and inequality in all aspects of le.ldquoThe Black Lives Matter movement is another form of protest against the injustice and inequalities they as a group face and have been facing for decades, he said.ldquoEquality is about ensuring that each person has an equal opportunity in society. For example, a personrsquos background, ethnicity, disability, skin colour, culture and religion should not determine or undermine these basic human rights. We work to eliminate all forms of discrimination and inequalities and promote human rights.When askedthere was a racism problem in East Lothian, Mr Choudhury said: ldquoYes we know there is a problem with racism because we deal with cases all the time so we know itrsquos still re in our communities.An example he gave involved a black man who was racially discriminated at work through how he was treated and dealt with by white members of staff.Staff are said to have made comments about his accent, racial jokes about his culture and where hersquos from.Mr Choudhury added: ldquoWe also have many cases of BAME residents who are racially abused by their neighbours and some have faced graffiti on their doors and car as well as verbal abuse on a daily basis. These are just a few of the issues we see on a regular basis.ldquoELREC as an organisation and board members, as well as our president Sir Geoff Palmer, are very active in Edinburgh and Lothians to do all we can to help our communities and society to fight racism at all levels.Conservative Councillor Craig Hoy, who represents the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, said:"Racism is abhorrent and should be called out and stamped out wherever it occurs."We all have a duty to confront racismand Isupport those who are campaigning here in East Lothian and across Scotland."

title: schoolgirl-draws-picture-thank-keyworker-parents
story: Lucy Malcolm, nine, lives near Pinkie Primary School with mum Dianne, who works in the maternity department at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh dad Keith, who works for Royal Mail -year-old brother James, an apprentice electrician and -year-old brother Craig, a pupil at Musselburgh Grammar School.Lucy, a primary four pupil at Campie Primary School, used chalk to draw the image without any help.Her gran Ann Malcolm, who lives on the townrsquos Riverside Gardens and is a former headteacher of Windygoul and Saltoun Primary Schools, said: ldquoItrsquos quite amazing.ldquoHer parents were taken aback and really appreciated it.ldquoSome of the neighbours also went over to have a look at it.ldquoThatrsquos what itrsquos all about, though, thanking these key workers and celebrating them.Ann said that the family have been coping well with lockdown, with Lucyrsquos brothers James and Craig helping to look after Lucy while their parents were at work.She added that she was looking forward to reuniting with the family and her grandchildren for a socially distanced chat.

title: east-lothians-tourism-industry-reopen-july
story: Tourism Secretary Fergus Ewing, MSP, today announced plans to allow tourism and hospitality sectors to reopen from July the country continues to move forward into the third phase of lting lockdown restrictions.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the move but warned comprehensive guidance would be needed to make sure the industry "got it right first time".He said: "Our tourism and hospitality sectors were among the first to be ordered to close as the Covid- lockdown began, which has had a devastating impact on many local businesses and visitor attractions.ldquoIt is welcome that they are now being given the go ahead to start planning to re-open, but we have to get this right first time. Businesses and others in the sector have faced huge financial losses due to this crisis, and there must be absolute clarity about what this announcement means for dferent parts of the sector.ldquoWith the possibility that this date could be pushed back for safety reasons, it is vital that Scotlandrsquos tourism and hospitality businesses, their staff and customers have absolute transparency from the Scottish Government about any potential changes that may need to be made."There must be comprehensive support and guidance made available to businesses and the public so that there is no confusion about how this can be handled safely.ldquoBusinesses in the tourism and hospitality will also need ongoing financial support through the recovery stage and I have written to the Finance Secretary to ask what the plans are for delivering this support.Last week Councillor Craig Hoy, ward member for Haddington and Lammermuir, wrote to East Lothian Councils chief executive Monica Patterson outlining his ideas for allowing restaurants, cafes and bars to reopen by making public spaces near them available to create an outdoor experience.Mr Hoy said: ldquoFor example, in Haddington the area outside of the Corn Exchange, the area to the front of the Waterside Bistro, the area outside of the former George Hotel and the area outside the Poldrate Centre, and the neighbouring riverside grassed area, could all be developed in this way, while ensuring hours of operation do not negatively impact local residents.A spokesperson for the council said at the time that it was already working with a range of stakeholders to ensure that local businesses can open as soon as Scottish Government guidance permits.

title: bus-stop-transformed-art-gallery-tyninghame
story: Tyninghame, like many communities across East Lothian, has worked hard to offer support and help to residents during lockdown.Throughout the pandemic, the village bus stop has become the central point for people to safely collect anything from teaching materials for children to the weekly vegetable order and tomato plants.Now, as lockdown restrictions are beginning to ease, Tyninghame residents are looking to the future.All have contributed pictures and collages to the Art in the Bus Stop project.Each work of art has been based around the theme of My Future Planet, with a community vote deciding the winners.

title: dunbar-residents-get-ready-civic-week-competition-home
story: The town would be gearing up for their annual Civic Week competition, which was due to get under way this weekend,it was not for the coronavirus.The global pandemic meant the popular event, which was due to mark its th anniversary, had to be cancelled.However, organisers came up with three competitions ndash a best dressed house, window and scarecrow ndash to ensure the milestone was still marked.Dunbar Community Council had planned week-long celebrations, which also would have toasted the th anniversary of the granting of a Burgh Charter to the town by King David II.George Robertson, who heads the organising committee of Civic Week, previously told the Courier the two milestones were ldquotoo important to be missed.The scarecrow should ideally represent any well-known person connected to Dunbar over the past  years, such as Oliver Cromwell, John Muir, Black Agnes or Robert Wilson.All entries should be sent in by pm this eveningto email address dunbarcivicweek@outlook with judging taking place on Saturday.

title: community-resilience-volunteers-longniddry-musselburgh-prestonpans-tranent
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.LongniddryTHE resilience team in Longniddry is starting to plan for the future as lockdown restrictions begin to ease, but it reminds residents that help is still availableneeded.The local effort is being run by Longniddry Parish Church and supported by the local community council.Those who need assistance are asked to call Sheila Jamieson on  .Sheila said: ldquoI think we should possibly be okay [for when restrictions start to ease].ldquoWe have got so many volunteers that evensome go back to work we should still have plenty of people to cover everything.There have been a few calls made to the resilience team during the past few weeks, and residents have been helping friends and neighbours.Some volunteers have also been chatting to people on the phone and supporting people where needed.Sheila added: ldquoI think people have been finding it easier to get online food shopping as well.ldquoWe are a very close-knit community, really. People are looking out for one another, everybody is known to somebody.MusselburghA CASH boost of pound, has been received by Resilient Musselburgh to support its continued community response during the Covid- crisis.The grant aid came from Edinburgh-based Corra Foundation, which helps improve the lives of iniduals and communities experiencing disadvantage across Scotland and in developing countries.Iain Clark, chairman of Musselburgh Area Partnership, said: ldquoOn a weekly basis, Resilient Musselburgh continues to provide needed food to those who have been identied through referral by the East Lothian Councilrsquos contact centre, other agencies, and via calls for assistance to the Resilient Musselburgh dedicated number.ldquoAll our support to the community is based on need and we continue to review that need as peoplersquos circumstances change.ldquoWe cannot thank enough the local and national organisations who are working with us to ensure that we can sustain our community support.ldquoThese include FareShare, Hickory Food, The Mercat Bar and Grill, Tesco Musselburgh, Pinkie Farm Shop and, most recently, BaxterStorey.ldquoWe received a large number of Easter eggs and cans of juice from The National Trust for Scotlandrsquos Newhailes House via Musselburgh Rotary Club and this has been welcomed.ldquoThe eggs are being distributed to children in the community.ldquoWe also received support from First Step Community Project, with resources for childrenrsquos activity packs.Iain added: ldquoYet again the kindness from our community continues and we keep our eyes open for opportunities to secure further funding to sustain our support over the coming months.ldquoWe are extremely grateful to Eskmuthe Rowing Club for their recent financial donation to Resilient Musselburgh.ldquoThe biggest thank you must go to our -plus volunteers who ensure that the support to the community continues.PrestonpansLOCKDOWN restrictions may have eased but there has been no reduction in the efforts of volunteers who remain committed to helping vulnerable residents in Prestonpans.Brian Weddell, Prestonpans Community Council chairman, said the resilience team was working as hard as ever to ensure everyone has access to supplies.And he urged people to help them continue to do their work safely by following the government guidelines.He said: ldquoThe focus over the past week has been on the relaxed rules and concern about people ignoring these new measures.ldquoClearly no one wants to see a negative outcome, with a second wave of Covid- cases jeopardising the chance of further relaxation of the strict rules still in place.ldquoWhilst the Scottish Government has relaxed lockdown rules, there has been no relaxation of the work of our willing team of volunteers, who continue to help deliver shopping, collect prescriptions and are doing dog walks.ldquoWhen you consider that some of our volunteers are still working, their support and commitment is really admirable.The community council paid a special tribute to the townrsquos acting SPoC , Allan Sneddon, who has continued to work during the crisis.Brian said: ldquoAllan has not only headed our resilience effort, he has led from the front, delivering meals, leaflets, shopping for elderly residents and doing the occasional dog walk.The Pennypit Pantry delivered nearly , meals last week, with  per cent of the deliveries going to the elderly.Brian said one of the nice spin-offs for volunteers has been the positive feedback from the people getting help.He said: ldquoAngie Davie from the Pennypit Trust has commented on the relationships she has built with a lot of the elderly people she delivers to.ldquoAngie says that shersquos become pretty attached to a lot of them and theyrsquore just so nice, thankful and are always up for a blether ndash which helps keeps us going.As well as the Pennypit Pantry, Jane Russellrsquos Sunday roast chicken dinners are still going strong and last weekend they delivered  dinners.The Sunday dinners can be ordered via East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinners on Facebook or by telephone on  .Finally, a reminder that Prestonpans Community Council has set up a hardship fund for people finding it dficult the longer the lockdown continues.Anyone needing support should telephone their resilience hotline number on   or email prestonpansresilience@gmailTranentTHE resilience team in Tranent and Elphinstone is starting to think about the next phase of its support plan, as requests for help slow down.For almost  weeks, a large number of volunteers have been assisting people in the local community, helping them with shopping, post office visits, dog walking, deliveries, posting leaflets and prescription uplts.The effort is led by Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council, overseen by member Mike Falconer, the grouprsquos single point of contact .Mike said: ldquoTranent volunteers have been outstanding now for nearly  weeks!ldquoThanks to all of you who have been helping out and, of course, thanks to all of you who maybe havenrsquot been called on yet ndash you have made yourself available and that is also a great help just knowing you are therewe need you ndash especially now, as folks start toto work and begin to pick up with some nearly normal le again.ldquoYou have all been wonderful.The resilience team also helps Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with meal deliveries, and has been supporting the school hub and its meal and lunch deliveries.Apart from food production and deliveries, other requests for help ldquoseem to be slowing down now, according to Mike.He said he is now starting to think about the next phase of the resilience teamrsquos support, something he calls the ldquorecovery phase. Volunteers will receive an email outlining how the group plans to do this. Those who need assistance can still call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmail

title: greywalls-preparing-welcome-back-guests
story: The redesigned luxury hotel will see diners able to order their meals using an app and food served to side tables to avoid contact.Rooms will be disinfected and sealed ahead of guests arrivals and staff will wear Personal Protective Equipment.Owners of the Gullane hotel, Inverlochy Castle Management International , say they hope to open on July  - a date announced by Tourism Secretary Fergus Ewing, MSP, today, depending on progress into phase three of the easing of lockdown.And the company, which also oversees Inverlochy Castle, Andy Murrayrsquos Cromlix, Crossbasket Castle, Blanefield House, among other venues and several rural self-catering lodges, says it aims to keep some of its services familiar while introducing additional measures to reasuure guests in a "post-covid world".It sais it has bought market-leading electrostatic fogging machines to fully disinfect all rooms, before they are sealed to ensure no contamination ahead of guest arrival and are introducing a one-way system and mandatory distancing with discreet signs as well as hands-free sanitising stations.Dining will change with a new app removing the need for menus and directories to help offer a contactless dining service and staggered dining services.All front and back of house employees will be provided with PPE and mandatory handwashing every  minutes will be introduced.Norbert Lieder, managing director of ICMI said: ldquoWe are excited to open our properties and give people who have spent several months in the confines of their own home the chance to remember luxury. Yes, the experience will be dferent as the result of our enhanced social distancing requirements, but a stay in one of our properties will be every bit as indulgent as it has always been.ldquoThe measures we have set out are on top of the already mammoth effort it takes to ensure that each destination ndash including castles, centuries-old properties and private islands ndash are ready to welcome guests both old and new as a base to unwind and perhaps rediscover some of the most beautul parts of the country.To check availability and for information on bookings visit www.greywalls.#

title: quietest-times-shop-asda-aldi-tesco-sainsburys
story: As lockdown continues to ease across the UK, analysis provided by Google visiting data has highlightedthebest times for shoppers to head out when less people are in stores.Heres a round-up from the top supermarket chains.AldiAldi stores are more likely to be quieter on weekdays, rather than on weekends.Those wanting to do a quick shop should avoid visiting their storiesat pm on Sundays, when the branches tend to be attheir busiest, with a wait time of up to  minutes expected.The quietest time to shop at Aldi tends to be before am and after pm on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays.AsdaFor shoppers heading to their local Asda store - the busiest days are usually Mondays and Fridays.The data also revealed that shoppers should expect to spend up to  minutes waiting on Mondays, when heading there between am and pm.The quieter days to shop are on Tuesdays, Wednesdays Thursdays and Sundays.SainsburysThose planning on a tripto Sainsburys should head there on Wednesdays, which tend to be the quietest day to shop there.Elsewhere, the busiest days for customers are on Fridays and Saturdays - with a -minute wait time between am and pm on a Friday, and a wait of minutes between pm and pm on a Saturday.TescoIf youre a Tesco shopper, its best to avoid their Express,and Superstores on Monday afternoons.On the other end of the scale, those wanting to carry out their essential shop should head out before midday and after pm on weekdays - as those are the quietest times.Customers can expect to wait up to  minutes between the hours of pm and pm on Saturdays - which tends to be the busiest time of the week.MorrisonsFinally, for those who head to their nearest Morrisons supermarket - best to avoid visiting on Saturdays at noon, with an average wait of up to half an hour.Its also busy in Morrisons on a Friday from pm until pm.The quietest day to go is on a Wednesday.

story: The new prompt, which will appearusers attempt to retweet an article posted by another user without first having clicked on it, is being trialled initially for Android users only.What have Twitter said about the change Twitter said: ldquoSharing an article can spark conversation, so you may want to read it before you tweet it.ldquoTo help promote informed discussion, wersquore testing a new prompt on Android ndash when you retweet an article that you havenrsquot opened on Twitter, we may askyoursquod like to open it first.The move comes amid continuing conversations about the spread of fake news on social media.Twitter product lead Kayvon Beykpour said: ldquoItrsquos easy for links articles to go viral on Twitter.ldquoThis can be powerful but sometimes dangerous, especiallypeople havenrsquot read the content theyrsquore spreading.ldquoThis feature ndash on Android for now ndash encourages people to read a linked article prior to retweeting it.Twitter has often received criticism for not doing enough to combat the spread of misinformation on its social media .Last month -it flagged two tweets from US President Donald Trump when he made unsubstantiated claims that postal voting would lead to widespread fraud.

title: five-alternative-fathers-day-experiences-lockdown
story: A day trip, family get together, a meal at dads favourite might have been on the cards to celebrate Fathers Day, but with our choices restricted this year due to lockdown there are some great alternatives out there.Your dad might be just as happy, or long for, playing a solitary round of golf at his local course or sitting by the riverbank waiting for his catch of the day, but might also want to come together with loved ones to celebrate his special day.From small garden gatherings, to Zoom parties, or virtual museum tours or a local stroll, we bring you the best ideas to make it a Fathers Day to remember.Virtual Museum TourWhile all their museums remain closed due to coronavirus, the National Museum of Scotland have opened their virtual doors for people to enter a world of discovery.Their website gives you the chance to explore their collections and discover more about amazing objects through stories, films, games and resources.There is the chance to delve into our animated adventures and find out more about le in ancient Egypt, learn some Mandarin. Watch videos on a day in the le of an ancient Egyptian priestPriests occupied a unique place in ancient Egyptian society. Find out what they did every day and why in this short animated film. Created for the Discovering Ancient Egypt gallery.There is also the chance to The East Asian CalendarThe East Asian calendar uses a unique system to measure and mark the passing of time. Discover the twelve animals in the calendar and find out what your animal sign is. Created for the East Asia gallery.For more information go to www.nms.ac.uk national-museum-of-scotland If you fancy going a little further afield in your virtual discovery why not take a look at the Louvre in Paris.Activities on offer at the online Louvre include:- One minute in a museum- YouTubers at the Louvre- Mona Lisa VR experience-  years of history- A closer look at Louvre artworksOr you can take a virtual tour of Founding Myths: From Hercules to Darth Vader.The Louvrersquos Petite Galerie first exhibition tells how illustrators, sculptors, painters, puppeteers, filmmakers, and musicians around the world have drawn inspiration from myths, given them form, and brought them to le.Local family walkNow we are allowed to exercise more than once a day and can meet up with another household, a walk near your home could be the ideal gathering.Check out the Ramblers Scotland website to find walks close to home of dfering levels. A great way to enjoy daily local exercise is to try one of their  free mapped Medal Routes short, circular walks in every local authority area in Scotland.Medal Routes are downloadable maps for short, fun circular walks of ,  or  minutes. They are available in every local authority area across Scotland and there are over  walking routes to choose from.The organisation has been working hard to help inspire people to keep active during lockdown - including via through their #RoamSweetHome campaign.If you are giving the Medal Routes a go in your local area during your daily exercise, they are looking for you to share photos or videos from your Medal Route walk by using the #RoamSweetHome hashtag or tagging us on social media.For more information got to www.ramblers.org.uk scotland.aspxGo for a bike rideSales of bikes have soared during lockdown with many shops now having waiting lists after being completely sold out. Transport Secretary Michael Matheson recently confirmed cycling levels are % higher compared with the lockdown baseline, while Cycling Scotlandrsquos automatic cycling counters at  spots around the country revealed remarkable results, with one in Dunfermline recording an increase of % since lockdown.There are a number of family routes to explore without going too far from home. National Cycle Network routes in Scotland run through many areas of outstanding natural beauty, taking in vast forests, iconic castles, shimmering lochs, tranquil glens and spectacular coastlines. The routes provide a unique snapshot of the countryrsquos rich history whilst also connecting all of Scotlands major cities.There are approximately , milesof National Cycle Network routes in Scotland, including  miles of traffic-free routes which use a mix of railway path, canal towpath, forest road, shared-use path, segregated cycle lanes and redetermined rural footways.More information can be found at www.sustrans.org.ukVirtual park discoveryWhile travelling too far afield might just be a distant dream at the moment, we will have to make do with exploring some parts of the great outdoors from our armchairs.Prepare to feel slightly dizzy on the virtual tour for Calornias Yosemite National Park. Virtual Yosemite is a groundbreaking interactive tour of one of Americarsquos most popular and spectacular natural environments. The project is unique in both the depth of its coverage and the quality of its imagery.It was created and photographed by pioneering virtual realityphotographer Scott Highton, who has specialized in VR photography since the early s.Virtual Yosemite allows online visitors to experience over  dferent locations within Yosemite and its surrounding areas, in all seasons. Over  percent of the locations covered are accessible to Yosemite visitors via roads or trails. The deg interactive panoramas are all presented in high resolution, so viewers can zoom in and out to see details, and can pan fully around, including looking upward and downward. Dizzying views from the tops of Yosemitersquos famous clfs and waterfalls are available, along with peaceful locations along trails and in well-known parts of Yosemite Valley.For more information go to www.virtualyosemite.org Closer to home enjoy an aerial view of Loch Lomond National Park under #Lochdown. See the beauty of nature during the coronavirus lochdown through a series of videos which have been posted on their website. Take in the enchanting Loch Achray, a small freshwater loch in the heart of the Trossachs.For more information go to https:www.lochlomond-trossachs.org park-authority lochdown aerial-tours-of-the-national-park Watch a dads favourite movieYou can now watch some streaming services together evenyou are not in the same household and it could be the answer to having a family movie night while social distancing or apart from dad this Fathers Day.Netflix is one example where you can watch the same film together. Netflix Party is a Google Chrome-exclusive extension that only requires one person to install it, making it easy to set up.Once you install it, choose a movie or show, pause it, and then click the red ldquoNP button at the top right of your browser to get a link to a shared session. The extension allows you to chat with everyone in the viewing session, but doesnrsquot allow you to put in a name, so yoursquoll have to remember your friendsrsquo random symbols.Netflix Party allows for full-screen viewing and anybody in the session can hit pause, play or scrub through the timeline.
